context: Ryan discusses vendor architecture and regulatory implications with a senior VP, explaining why a legacy decision was made, where it creates misaligned responsibility, and how acquisition context (Skygrid) may change the optimal design.

text.msg: Airline is having SG as a vendor? And we're feeding that data to RSS? seems backward

ðŸ¥² yes.... you're touching a nerve.

As a result of DMP-1602 we inherited a function that doesn't really fall within our scope but is otherwise homeless...
why was this seen as a good idea?

So that the RSS can be vendor agnostic...
[explains certified software vs industry adaptability tradeoff]
and does this change now that SG is selling to ANSPs (not operators)?

Actually... SG selling to ANSPs rather than operators does change that a bit...
[describes redistribution and Gen 6 super system implications]
on this graphic on slide 10... why does OEM need to know Airline's ICDs to the DO-200B data?

It is, and functionally it will be as much of a pass-through as we can make it...
[explains compliance inheritance risk]
so the DO-200B data DOES flow from Airline to RSS now?

yes. at least through an appliance that it is now within the airline's scope to develop...
[describes mitigation via reusable module]

internal.thought: I acknowledge the flaw immediately to establish trust, then explain the original rationale before critiquing outcomes.
I defend the architectural intent without defending the result, which keeps the conversation productive.
I clarify regulatory inheritance risk carefully to avoid triggering unnecessary fear while still being honest about effort.
I offer a mitigation path that preserves scalability and reuse rather than framing it as a local problem.
